mixSQP

Illustration of mix-SQP solver applied to a small data set, and a large one

Youngseok Kim and Peter Carbonetto

2018-10-03

In this vignette, we compare the runtime and accuracy of the mix-SQP algorithm against an interior-point (IP) solver implemented by the MOSEK commercial software (and called via the “KWDual” function in the REBayes package).

Environment set-up

We begin by loading the mixSQP and Rmosek packages. (The Rmosek package is only needed to check the version of MOSEK interior-point solver being used.)

library(mixSQP)
library(Rmosek)

Next, initialize the sequence of pseudorandom numbers.

set.seed(1)

Generate a small data set

Let’s begin with a smaller example with \(n=\) 50,000 samples.

L <- simulatemixdata(5e4,10)$L
dim(L)
# [1] 50000    10

This call to simulatemixdata created an \(n \times k\) conditional likelihood matrix for a mixture of zero-centered normals, with \(m = 10\). Note that the rows of the likelihood matrix are normalized by default so that the maximum entry in each row is 1.

Fit mixture model

First, we fit the mixture model using the mix-SQP solver.

timing.sqp <- system.time(fit.sqp <- mixSQP(L))
cat(sprintf("Computation took %0.2f seconds.\n",timing.sqp["elapsed"]))
# Running mix-SQP 0.1-22 on 50000 x 10 matrix
# convergence tol. (SQP): 1.0e-08
# max. iter (SQP):        1000
# max. iter (active-set): 100
# zero threshold:         1.0e-06
# iter    objective max.diff max(rdual) nnz nqp nls
#    1 +7.51074e-01       NA +2.614e-01  10  NA  NA
#    2 +6.66166e-01 3.01e-01 +4.509e+00   4  17   1
#    3 +6.18728e-01 6.51e-02 +2.125e+00   4   8   1
#    4 +6.12130e-01 1.08e-02 +9.295e-01   4   2   1
#    5 +6.11262e-01 1.11e-02 +3.686e-01   4   2   1
#    6 +6.09558e-01 1.87e-02 +1.691e-01   5   4   1
#    7 +6.07030e-01 4.19e-02 +5.931e-02   5   2   1
#    8 +6.05031e-01 2.47e-02 +1.114e-02   5   2   1
#    9 +6.04453e-01 5.70e-03 +5.031e-04   5   2   1
#   10 +6.04423e-01 2.57e-04 +1.080e-06   5   2   1
#   11 +6.04423e-01 5.41e-07 +4.667e-11   5   2   1
# Convergence criteria met---optimal solution found.
# Computation took 0.09 seconds.

Next, we fit the same mixture model using the IP solver.

timing.ip <- system.time(fit.ip <- mixKWDual(L))
cat(sprintf("Computation took %0.2f seconds.\n",timing.ip["elapsed"]))
# Computation took 1.16 seconds.

The runtime of the mix-SQP algorithm is less than the IP method, and the quality of the IP and SQP solutions is very similar.

cat(sprintf("Objective at SQP solution: %0.16f\n",fit.sqp$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Objective at IP solution:  %0.16f\n",fit.ip$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Difference in objectives:  %0.4e\n",fit.sqp$value - fit.ip$value))
# Objective at SQP solution: 0.6044234133387498
# Objective at IP solution:  0.6044234133023487
# Difference in objectives:  3.6401e-11

Comparison using a large data set

Next, let’s see what happens when we apply the IP and SQP methods algorithms to a considerably larger data set.

As before, we compute the \(n \times m\) likelihood matrix for a mixture of zero-centered normals. This time, we use a finer grid of \(m = 50\) normal densities, as well as more samples.

L <- simulatemixdata(1e5,50)$L
dim(L)
# [1] 100000     50

Now we fit the model using the two fitting algorithms.

timing.ip  <- system.time(fit.ip  <- mixKWDual(L))
timing.sqp <- system.time(fit.sqp <- mixSQP(L))
# Running mix-SQP 0.1-22 on 100000 x 50 matrix
# convergence tol. (SQP): 1.0e-08
# max. iter (SQP):        1000
# max. iter (active-set): 100
# zero threshold:         1.0e-06
# iter    objective max.diff max(rdual) nnz nqp nls
#    1 +7.71366e-01       NA +2.220e-01  50  NA  NA
#    2 +6.89004e-01 3.95e-01 +7.084e+01   5  74   1
#    3 +6.36556e-01 1.20e-01 +1.329e+01   5  35   1
#    4 +6.27735e-01 2.31e-01 +3.329e+00   4   9   1
#    5 +6.21354e-01 1.58e-01 +7.675e-01   5  31   1
#    6 +6.18476e-01 2.32e-01 +1.513e-01   5   8   1
#    7 +6.16313e-01 9.14e-02 +1.538e-02   5  23   1
#    8 +6.15714e-01 8.53e-02 +7.038e-04   6   4   1
#    9 +6.15602e-01 2.36e-02 +1.843e-05   6   5   1
#   10 +6.15599e-01 5.64e-04 +1.173e-08   6   2   1
#   11 +6.15599e-01 3.47e-07 +4.955e-11   6   2   1
# Convergence criteria met---optimal solution found.

The mix-SQP algorithm algorithm is again faster than the IP solver.

cat(sprintf("Runtime of IP solver:  %0.2f\n",timing.ip["elapsed"]))
cat(sprintf("Runtime of SQP solver: %0.2f\n",timing.sqp["elapsed"]))
# Runtime of IP solver:  6.31
# Runtime of SQP solver: 2.01

Further, the quality of the IP and SQP solutions remains very similar:

cat(sprintf("Objective at SQP solution: %0.16f\n",fit.sqp$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Objective at IP solution:  %0.16f\n",fit.ip$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Difference in objectives:  %0.4e\n",fit.sqp$value - fit.ip$value))
# Objective at SQP solution: 0.6155985724828708
# Objective at IP solution:  0.6155985724520242
# Difference in objectives:  3.0847e-11

Session information

This next code chunk gives information about the computing environment used to generate the results contained in this vignette, including the version of R and the packages used.

sessionInfo()
# R version 3.4.3 (2017-11-30)
# Platform: x86_64-apple-darwin15.6.0 (64-bit)
# Running under: macOS High Sierra 10.13.6
# 
# Matrix products: default

# 
# locale:
# [1] en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/C/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8
# 
# attached base packages:
# [1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     
# 
# other attached packages:
# [1] Rmosek_8.0.69 Matrix_1.2-12 mixSQP_0.1-27
# 
# loaded via a namespace (and not attached):
#  [1] Rcpp_0.12.19    lattice_0.20-35 digest_0.6.17   rprojroot_1.3-2
#  [5] grid_3.4.3      backports_1.1.2 magrittr_1.5    evaluate_0.11

# [13] REBayes_1.3     yaml_2.2.0      compiler_3.4.3  htmltools_0.3.6
# [17] knitr_1.20

Since we used Rmosek, it is also helpful to record the version of MOSEK that was used.

mosek_version()
# [1] "MOSEK 8.1.0.27"
